title.narrative: Maisha Bora - Belgian Food Security Programme for the Districts of Longido and Simanjiro - 2015-2020 - TRIAS
Maisha Bora - Belgian Food Security Programme for the Districts of Longido and Simanjiro - business development, ecotourism & food budgetting and savings components

description.narrative: - Women organised in VICOBAs - Youth - Member Based Organisations - The district government in Longido and Simanjiro district

TRIAS and its Tanzanian partners will be responsible for the implementation of Result 2 of the Maisha bora programme. TRIAS aims to achieve the objective by working on the following four results: • Result 1 : Women and youth have improved income from small and micro businesses • Result 2 : Improved enabling environment for development of small and micro businesses of women and youth and for livestock business development • Result 3 : Relatively more of households livestock and livestock products are sold at a better price and income from livestock is used to buy more food or to save • Result 4: Partner organisations and district governments in the two districts have improved their capacities The intervention strategy is based on the linkage of a bottom-up and a top-down approach. We will work as well on grass roots local economic development as on the improvement of the business environment in the two districts. We foresee an important role in linking the 15 villages to rural business hubs which will serve as interfaces with the most important markets in the area (mainly Namanga, Arusha and Nairobi). The proposed 5-year project will contribute to the development objective of improved food security of households in 15 targeted villages in Longido District in Arusha Region and Simanjiro District in Manyara Region. The specific objective that the project aims to achieve is: "higher and more secured income used for nutrition and improved local availability of food for 9,000 households in 15 villages in Simanjiro and Longido districts, and in particular for the 40% of impoverished households, women and youth."

The programme is a multi-actor programme for which BFFS has selected 5 partner organizations. Each partner has the responsibility for the implementation of a specific component or (sub)-result of the programme. The major components are: securing livestock resources and that households benefit form livestock products, securing access to water points for livestock holders, business development of livestock and improved income and diversification of women, youth and targeted households, improved access and utilization.
